elements.content: A complex cascade of solid-state processes initiated by variation of temperature was found for the heterospin complex [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et] formed in the reaction of copper­(II) hexafluoroacetylacetonate [Cu­(hfac)2] with stable nitronyl nitroxide 2-(1-methyl-3-ethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)-4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-4,5-dihydro-1H-imidazole-3-oxide-1-oxyl (LMe/Et). The cooling of the compound below 260 K initiated a solid-state chemical reaction, which led to a depolymerization of chains and formation of a pair heterospin complex [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et 2]­[[Cu­(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2]. Further decrease in temperature below 144 K led to a spin transition accompanied by a drastic decrease in the effective magnetic moment from 2.52 to 2.24 μB. When the compound was heated, the order of effects was reversed: at first, the magnetic moment abruptly increased, and then the molecular fragments of the pair cluster united into polymer chains. Two hysteresis loops correspond to this cascade of temperature-induced structural transformations on the experimental dependence μeff(T): one at high (T↑ = 283 K and T↓ = 260 K) and the other at low (T↑ = 161 K, T↓ = 144 K) temperature. The spin transitions were also recorded for the [[Cu­(hfac)2]3LBu/Et 2] and [[Cu­(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] molecular complexes, which are models of the trinuclear fragment of the {[Cu­(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2} pair cluster.

Two hysteresis loops correspond to this cascade of temperature-induced structural transformations on the experimental dependence μeff(T): one at high (T↑ = 283 K and T↓ = 260 K) and the other at low (T↑ = 161 K, T↓ = 144 K) temperature. elements.content: For [Cu­(hfac)2(nitroxide)] crystals, a cascade of reversible transformations was found during repeated cooling−heating cycles including coordination depolymerization−polymerization and spin transition.
elements.clean_text: For [Cu(hfac)2(nitroxide)] crystals, a cascade of reversible transformations was found during repeated cooling-heating cycles including coordination depolymerization-polymerization and spin transition.

elements.content: The development of methods for the synthesis of Cu­(II) complexes with nitroxides underlies the creation of unusual heterospin compounds, which exhibit thermo- and photoinduced spin transitions. Since the classic spin crossover is impossible in Cu­(II) complexes with diamagnetic ligands, including the diamagnetic structural analogs of nitroxides, an essential condition for this effect is coordination of an additional paramagnetic center, i.e., formation of at least a two-center exchange cluster. A spin-crossover-like phenomenon is observed when the external effect changes the mutual orientation of the paramagnetic centers and consequently the character of interaction of odd electrons. The thermally induced change in the distances between the paramagnetic centers in the {>N–•O–Cu­(II)} or {>N–•O–Cu­(II)–O•–N<} exchange clusters generally leads to an abrupt change in the energy and/or sign of the exchange interaction, which just gives rise to an anomaly on the curve of the temperature dependence of the effective magnetic moment (μeff). The high sensitivity of the physical characteristics of this anomaly to external treatment opens up prospects for creating new spin devices, namely, multispin sensors and actuators. Thus, a Cu­(II) complex with nitronyl nitroxide was recently described, which is extremely sensitive to the external pressure in the solid state. The spin transition temperature of the complex abruptly changes with the external pressure, serving as an indicator of the external action. In addition, the indication can be optical because the compound changes color during the transition.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The development of methods for the synthesis of Cu(II) complexes with nitroxides underlies the creation of unusual heterospin compounds, which exhibit thermo- and photoinduced spin transitions. Since the classic spin crossover is impossible in Cu(II) complexes with diamagnetic ligands, including the diamagnetic structural analogs of nitroxides, an essential condition for this effect is coordination of an additional paramagnetic center, i.e., formation of at least a two-center exchange cluster. A spin-crossover-like phenomenon is observed when the external effect changes the mutual orientation of the paramagnetic centers and consequently the character of interaction of odd electrons. The thermally induced change in the distances between the paramagnetic centers in the {>N-⋅O-Cu(II)} or {>N-⋅O-Cu(II)-O⋅-N<} exchange clusters generally leads to an abrupt change in the energy and/or sign of the exchange interaction, which just gives rise to an anomaly on the curve of the temperature dependence of the effective magnetic moment (μeff). The high sensitivity of the physical characteristics of this anomaly to external treatment opens up prospects for creating new spin devices, namely, multispin sensors and actuators. Thus, a Cu(II) complex with nitronyl nitroxide was recently described, which is extremely sensitive to the external pressure in the solid state. The spin transition temperature of the complex abruptly changes with the external pressure, serving as an indicator of the external action. In addition, the indication can be optical because the compound changes color during the transition.

elements.content: The number of structural parameters that change in the course of a spin-crossover-like phenomenon is generally very large. A detailed study of magnetostructural correlations inherent in heterospin compounds is possible only when the single crystals of the complexes retain their quality during the phase transition. Therefore, a study of heterospin complexes should rely on compounds whose crystals possess high mechanical plasticity, due to which the single crystal-to-single crystal (SC–SC) phase transformations can be studied.

A detailed study of magnetostructural correlations inherent in heterospin compounds is possible only when the single crystals of the complexes retain their quality during the phase transition. Therefore, a study of heterospin complexes should rely on compounds whose crystals possess high mechanical plasticity, due to which the single crystal-to-single crystal (SC-SC) phase transformations can be studied.

elements.content: Also note a considerable change in the intramolecular geometrical characteristics in heterospin complexes in the course of SC–SC transformations. Inside the coordination polyhedron, the O···O distance on the ONO–Cu–ONO axis can be shortened or lengthened by more than an angstrom after repeated cooling–heating cycles during the phase transition. Despite the considerable local migrations of atoms, the change in the intermolecular contacts between the paramagnetic centers as a result of the phase transformation can still be more pronounced. Sometimes it is so large that topotactic polymerization is initiated in the solid heterospin complex on cooling, during which the neighboring molecules come closer by approximately 2 Å.

Inside the coordination polyhedron, the O⋅⋅⋅O distance on the ONO-Cu-ONO axis can be shortened or lengthened by more than an angstrom after repeated cooling-heating cycles during the phase transition. Despite the considerable local migrations of atoms, the change in the intermolecular contacts between the paramagnetic centers as a result of the phase transformation can still be more pronounced. Sometimes it is so large that topotactic polymerization is initiated in the solid heterospin complex on cooling, during which the neighboring molecules come closer by approximately 2 Å.

elements.content: The SC–SC coordination polymerization was first described by Cheng and Foxman, who reported the transformation of mononuclear NiBr2(CEP)2 (CEP = P­(CH2CH2CN)3) into a chain polymer, which was accelerated on heating. They also noted some very important peculiarities of the process both at the micro and macro level. Though SC–SC processes offer a unique possibility for detailed studies of solid-state transformations, there are few examples of SC–SC polymerization–depolymerizations of coordination compounds occurring as a result of the thermally induced intracrystal approach or removal of the metal atom of a molecule and the donor atom of the neighboring molecule.

They also noted some very important peculiarities of the process both at the micro and macro level. Though SC-SC processes offer a unique possibility for detailed studies of solid-state transformations, there are few examples of SC-SC polymerization-depolymerizations of coordination compounds occurring as a result of the thermally induced intracrystal approach or removal of the metal atom of a molecule and the donor atom of the neighboring molecule.

elements.content: We found an SC–SC reversible transformation when investigating the properties of a heterospin compound based on the Cu­(hfac)2 complex with the stable nitronyl nitroxide 2-(1-methyl-3-ethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)-4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-4,5-dihydro-1H-imidazole-3-oxide-1-oxyl (LMe/Et). The heating of the compound initiated a topotactic solid-state reaction in it, which led to the formation of polymer chains, while the cooling destroyed the polymer chains, converting the compound into a heterospin molecular complex. Coordination depolymerization initiated by a decrease in temperature is a very rare occurrence. For complexes with paramagnetic ligands, it was found for the first time.

Coordination depolymerization initiated by a decrease in temperature is a very rare occurrence. For complexes with paramagnetic ligands, it was found for the first time.

elements.content: The progress of the reactions was monitored by TLC on Silica gel 60 F254 aluminum sheets (Merck). The chromatography was carried out using silica gel (0.063–0.200 mm, Merck) for column chromatography. The infrared spectrum of nitroxide LMe/Et (4000–400 cm–1) was recorded with a Bruker VECTOR 22 instrument for a KBr pellet. The microanalysis was performed on a HEKAtech GmbH EA–3000 analyzer. The mass spectrum was recorded on a DFS (Thermo Electron) high-resolution mass spectrometer. The synthesis of 1-methyl-3-ethyl-1H-pyrazole and a mixture of 1-butyl-3(5)-ethyl-1H-pyrazoles was described elsewhere, respectively. 4-Formylpyrazoles were prepared by the procedure reported elsewhere.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

The progress of the reactions was monitored by TLC on Silica gel 60 F254 aluminum sheets (Merck). The chromatography was carried out using silica gel (0.063-0.200 mm, Merck) for column chromatography. The infrared spectrum of nitroxide LMe/Et (4000-400 cm-1) was recorded with a Bruker VECTOR 22 instrument for a KBr pellet. The microanalysis was performed on a HEKAtech GmbH EA-3000 analyzer. The mass spectrum was recorded on a DFS (Thermo Electron) high-resolution mass spectrometer. The synthesis of 1-methyl-3-ethyl-1H-pyrazole and a mixture of 1-butyl-3(5)-ethyl-1H-pyrazoles was described elsewhere, respectively. 4-Formylpyrazoles were prepared by the procedure reported elsewhere.

elements.content: 1-Methyl-3-ethylpyrazole (11.02 g, 0.1 mol) was dissolved in DMF (36 g, 0.5 mol), and POCl3 was added dropwise (30.66 g, 0.2 mol). The reaction mixture was stirred for 5 h at 70–75 °C and then poured in cold water (200 mL); pH of the solution was brought to 7 or 8 with a saturated NaHCO3 solution. The precipitate was filtered off and dried in air. Yield: 8.28 g (60%). T b = 132–134 °C/15 Torr. 1H NMR spectrum (δ, ppm, J H,H, Hz) (400.13 MHz), CDCl3: 1.26 t (3H, CH3, J = 7.6), 2.86 qu (2H CH2, J = 7.6), 3.88 s (3H, NCH3), 7.82 s (1H, C5H), 9.86 s (1H, HCO). Found (%): C 60.9; H 7.3; N 20.3. Calculated for C7H10N2O (%): C 60.8; H 7.4; N 20.1. A mixture of 1-butyl-3(5)-ethyl-1H-pyrazole-4-carboxaldehydes was prepared from 1-butyl-3(5)-ethylpyrazoles (15.24 g, 0.1 mol), DMF (36 g, 0.5 mol), and POCl3 (30.66 g, 0.2 mol) by the same procedure. Yield: 12.24 g (68%); isomer ratio ≈ 1:1. T b = 150–154 °C/15 Torr). Found (%): C 66.6; H 9.0; N 15.5. Calculated for C10H16N2O (%): C 66.8; H 8.9; N 15.6.

elements.content: A solution of 2,3-bis­(hydroxyamino)-2,3-dimethylbutane sulfate hydrate (3.15 g, 11.8 mmol) in water (50 mL) and a mixture of 1-butyl-3(5)-ethyl-1H-pyrazole-4-carboxaldehyde (1.8 g, 10.0 mmol) with Et2O (15 mL) was stirred for 4 h at room temperature and treated with NaHCO3 until CO2 ceased to evolve. The resulting precipitate was filtered off, washed with water and acetone, and dried in a vacuum desiccator. The resulting adduct (1.35 g, 4.4 mmol) was stirred in CH3OH (7 mL) with MnO2 (6.75 g, 77.5 mmol) for 1.5 h. The reaction mixture was filtered, and the precipitate washed with CH3OH. The filtrate was evaporated, and the residue dissolved in a minimum amount of ethyl acetate. The resulting solution was filtered through a silica gel layer (1.5 × 15 cm) and evaporated. The nitroxides containing a butyl and ethyl substituent in the first and third positions of the pyrazole ring (LBu/Et) or in the first and fifth positions of the pyrazole ring (LBu/Et*), respectively, were prepared as a mixture of blue oily products. Yield: 1.1 g (82%). IR (KBr, cm–1): ν = 3415 (m), 3124 (w), 2961 (s), 2873 (s), 1678 (s), 1585 (s), 1541 (m), 1508 (m), 1456 (s), 1395 (s), 1358 (s), 1320 (m), 1221 (m), 1173 (s), 1141 (s), 1114 (w), 1058 (w), 1012 (w), 962 (w), 871 (m), 830 (m), 791 (w), 761 (w), 655 (w), 614 (w), 541 (m), 463 (w). The high-resolution mass spectrum was recorded on Thermo Electron DFS (EI 70 eV, 10–7 mTorr, direct insertion probe on a heated stock). Found: m/z 307.2130 [M+]. C16H27N4O2. Calculated: M = 307.2129. Mass spectrum, m/z (I rel(%)): 41.0 (14.2), 69.1 (35.9), 84.1 (100), 98.1 (19.8), 178.1 (12.1), 275.2 (12.7), 307.2 (42.2).

elements.content: A mixture of Cu­(hfac)2 (0.0477 g, 0.1 mmol) and oily LBu/Et and LBu/Et* (0.0400 g, 0.13 mmol) was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (2 mL). The solution was evaporated, and the residue dissolved, while treating it ultrasonically, in hexane (2 mL). The resulting solution was cooled and stored at −30 °C for 6–8 h. The resulting dark red needle crystals of the poorly soluble [Cu­(hfac)2LBu/Et*]2 were filtered off and washed with cold hexane. The mother solution was heated to room temperature, and its volume was decreased to a few milliters, while blowing it with an air current, and then stored at −18 °C for another 30 h. The resulting brown crystals were separated by filtration. Yield: 0.0246 g (25%). Found (%): C, 36.6; H, 2.9; F, 32.9; N, 5.7. C62H60Cu3F36N8O16. Calculated (%): C, 36.4; H, 3.0; F, 33.4; N, 5.5. IR (KBr, cm–1): ν = 2969 (m), 1643 (s), 1595 (m), 1559 (m), 1529 (m), 1481 (s), 1396 (w), 1359 (m), 1263 (s), 1209 (s), 1147 (s), 872 (w), 850 (w), 800 (s), 769 (w), 746 (w), 679 (s), 595 (m), 530 (m).

elements.content: A mixture of Cu­(hfac)2 (0.0477 g, 0.1 mmol) and oily LBu/Et and LBu/Et* (0.0307 g, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in Et2O (3 mL). Then hexane (3 mL) was added. The reaction mixture was cooled to −18 °C. After 3 days, the precipitated [Cu­(hfac)2LBu/Et*]2 crystals were separated by filtration. A seed crystal of the desired product was introduced in the mother solution, and the reaction mixture was stored for another 3 days at −18 °C. The yield of [[Cu­(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] was 0.019 g (50%). Found (%): C, 37.4; H, 3.3; F, 31.6; N, 6.3. C114H118Cu5F60N16O28. Calculated (%): C, 37.8; H, 3.3; F, 31.5; N, 6.2. IR (KBr, cm–1): ν = 2969 (m), 1643 (s), 1595 (m), 1559 (m), 1529 (m), 1481 (s), 1396 (w), 1359 (m), 1263 (s), 1209 (s), 1147 (s), 872 (w), 850 (w), 800 (s), 769 (w), 746 (w), 679 (s), 595 (m), 530 (m).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [[Cu(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4]

A mixture of Cu(hfac)2 (0.0477 g, 0.1 mmol) and oily LBu/Et and LBu/Et* (0.0307 g, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in Et2O (3 mL). Then hexane (3 mL) was added. The reaction mixture was cooled to -18 °C. After 3 days, the precipitated [Cu(hfac)2LBu/Et*]2 crystals were separated by filtration. A seed crystal of the desired product was introduced in the mother solution, and the reaction mixture was stored for another 3 days at -18 °C. The yield of [[Cu(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] was 0.019 g (50%). Found (%): C, 37.4; H, 3.3; F, 31.6; N, 6.3. C114H118Cu5F60N16O28. Calculated (%): C, 37.8; H, 3.3; F, 31.5; N, 6.2. IR (KBr, cm-1): ν = 2969 (m), 1643 (s), 1595 (m), 1559 (m), 1529 (m), 1481 (s), 1396 (w), 1359 (m), 1263 (s), 1209 (s), 1147 (s), 872 (w), 850 (w), 800 (s), 769 (w), 746 (w), 679 (s), 595 (m), 530 (m).

elements.content: Note: [[Cu­(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] is the kinetic product; if a seed crystal of the desired product is not introduced in the system under the above-described conditions of synthesis, the solid product is a mixture of [[Cu­(hfac)2]3LBu/Et 2] and [[Cu­(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] crystals. The crystals of these compounds are difficult to distinguish because they are similar in both color and habit. An unambiguous identification of these crystals requires an X-ray diffraction study. When the synthesis of [[Cu­(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] was repeated several times, the solid product was completely [[Cu­(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] crystals only once.

The crystals of these compounds are difficult to distinguish because they are similar in both color and habit. An unambiguous identification of these crystals requires an X-ray diffraction study. When the synthesis of [[Cu(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] was repeated several times, the solid product was completely [[Cu(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] crystals only once.

elements.content: The intensity data for single crystals of LMe/Et, [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et], [[Cu­(hfac)2]3LBu/Et 2], and [[Cu­(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] were collected on a SMART APEX CCD (Bruker AXS) automated diffractometer with a Helix (Oxford Cryosystems) open flow helium cooler using the standard procedure (Mo Kα radiation). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares procedure anisotropically for non-hydrogen atoms. The H atoms were calculated geometrically and included in the refinement as riding groups. All calculations were fulfilled with the SHELXTL 6.14 program package. The experimental details and selected bond lengths and angles are summarized in Tables 1S and 2S.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The intensity data for single crystals of LMe/Et, [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et], [[Cu(hfac)2]3LBu/Et 2], and [[Cu(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] were collected on a SMART APEX CCD (Bruker AXS) automated diffractometer with a Helix (Oxford Cryosystems) open flow helium cooler using the standard procedure (Mo Kα radiation). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares procedure anisotropically for non-hydrogen atoms. The H atoms were calculated geometrically and included in the refinement as riding groups. All calculations were fulfilled with the SHELXTL 6.14 program package. The experimental details and selected bond lengths and angles are summarized in Tables 1S and 2S.

elements.content: Magnetic measurements were carried out on an MPMSXL SQUID magnetometer (Quantum Design) in the temperature range 2–325 K in a magnetic field of up to 5 kOe. The molar magnetic susceptibility was calculated using diamagnetic corrections for the complexes according to the Pascal scheme. The effective magnetic moment was calculated as μeff(T) = [(3k/N AμB 2)χT]1/2 ≈ (8χT)1/2. Variation of the heating or cooling rate of the samples (5–10 K/min) did not affect the form of the μeff(T) dependence. Its form was also the same for samples from different syntheses.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Measurements

Magnetic measurements were carried out on an MPMSXL SQUID magnetometer (Quantum Design) in the temperature range 2-325 K in a magnetic field of up to 5 kOe. The molar magnetic susceptibility was calculated using diamagnetic corrections for the complexes according to the Pascal scheme. The effective magnetic moment was calculated as μeff(T) = [(3k/N AμB 2)χT]1/2 ~ (8χT)1/2. Variation of the heating or cooling rate of the samples (5-10 K/min) did not affect the form of the μeff(T) dependence. Its form was also the same for samples from different syntheses.

elements.content: The isotropic exchange parameters were estimated within the broken-symmetry approach using the scheme proposed by Yamaguchi and co-workers. All calculations were performed using the crystallographically determined geometries and the UB3LYP/TZVP calculation procedure as implemented in the Gaussian09 package. According to calculations, the exchange interactions in [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et 2]­[[Cu­(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2] and [[Cu­(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] are localized within the {>N–•O–Cu­(II)} and {>N–•O–Cu­(II)–O•–N<} fragments (exchange clusters). Thus, [[Cu­(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2] consists of two noninteracting terminal copper ions and the central {>N–•O–Cu­(II)–O•–N<} exchange cluster, while [[Cu­(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] contains two terminal {>N–•O–Cu­(II)} exchange clusters and the central {>N–•O–Cu­(II)–O•–N<} exchange cluster separated by two noninteracting copper ions.
elements.clean_text:
Quantum-Chemical Calculations

The isotropic exchange parameters were estimated within the broken-symmetry approach using the scheme proposed by Yamaguchi and co-workers. All calculations were performed using the crystallographically determined geometries and the UB3LYP/TZVP calculation procedure as implemented in the Gaussian09 package. According to calculations, the exchange interactions in [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et 2][[Cu(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2] and [[Cu(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] are localized within the {>N-⋅O-Cu(II)} and {>N-⋅O-Cu(II)-O⋅-N<} fragments (exchange clusters). Thus, [[Cu(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2] consists of two noninteracting terminal copper ions and the central {>N-⋅O-Cu(II)-O⋅-N<} exchange cluster, while [[Cu(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] contains two terminal {>N-⋅O-Cu(II)} exchange clusters and the central {>N-⋅O-Cu(II)-O⋅-N<} exchange cluster separated by two noninteracting copper ions.

elements.content: High-spin state geometry optimizations and single point energy calculations of the [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et 2] and [Cu­(hfac)2LBu/Et 2] model complexes containing the {CuO4N2} or {CuO5N} coordination units were performed without imposing symmetry constraints using the same calculation procedure (see above).
elements.clean_text: High-spin state geometry optimizations and single point energy calculations of the [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et 2] and [Cu(hfac)2LBu/Et 2] model complexes containing the {CuO4N2} or {CuO5N} coordination units were performed without imposing symmetry constraints using the same calculation procedure (see above).

elements.content: To control the accuracy of Gaussian09 calculations, all magnetic coupling constants in the isolated exchange clusters were recalculated using the ORCA 3.0 quantum chemistry package within the same spin-unrestricted broken symmetry approach at the UB3LYP/def2-TZVP level of DFT.
elements.clean_text: To control the accuracy of Gaussian09 calculations, all magnetic coupling constants in the isolated exchange clusters were recalculated using the ORCA 3.0 quantum chemistry package within the same spin-unrestricted broken symmetry approach at the UB3LYP/def2-TZVP level of DFT.

elements.content: For independent evaluation of exchange parameters in the molecular systems, we also used an approach based on band structure calculations. For band structure calculations, the pseudo-potential PW-SCF code of the Quantum Espresso 5.0 package was used. We used the ultrasoft pseudo-potentials with a nonlinear core correction and the PBE version of the exchange-correlation potential. The kinetic energy cutoffs for wave functions and charge density are 35 and 280 Ry, respectively. The integration in the k space in the course of self-consistency was performed over the mesh 2 × 2 × 2 in the first Brillouin zone as in Monkhorst–Pack scheme with displacement of the k-grid at the center of the Brillouin zone and Gaussian smoothing of 0.136 eV. The Hubbard correlations on Cu sites were taken into account within the framework of the GGA+U approximation in the rotationally invariant version by Dudarev with U d(Cu) = 9.8 eV, U p(O) = 5.0 eV.
elements.clean_text: For independent evaluation of exchange parameters in the molecular systems, we also used an approach based on band structure calculations. For band structure calculations, the pseudo-potential PW-SCF code of the Quantum Espresso 5.0 package was used. We used the ultrasoft pseudo-potentials with a nonlinear core correction and the PBE version of the exchange-correlation potential. The kinetic energy cutoffs for wave functions and charge density are 35 and 280 Ry, respectively. The integration in the k space in the course of self-consistency was performed over the mesh 2 × 2 × 2 in the first Brillouin zone as in Monkhorst-Pack scheme with displacement of the k-grid at the center of the Brillouin zone and Gaussian smoothing of 0.136 eV. The Hubbard correlations on Cu sites were taken into account within the framework of the GGA+U approximation in the rotationally invariant version by Dudarev with U d(Cu) = 9.8 eV, U p(O) = 5.0 eV.

elements.content: The brown crystals of the [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et] heterospin complex are readily isolated with a high yield from the hexane solution of the equimolar amounts of Cu­(hfac)2 and LMe/Et. The synthesis of [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et] is reproducible, and no impurities with another stoichiometry were recorded in the product. The structural study of [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et] showed that under the normal conditions, its solid phase is formed by [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et] n polymer chains, in which the nitroxide molecules are orientated according to the head-to-head motif (). Each LMe/Et molecule performs the bridging function and is coordinated by the alternating Cu atoms or by the N atom of the pyrazole ring or the O atom of the nitronyl nitroxyl fragment.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The brown crystals of the [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et] heterospin complex are readily isolated with a high yield from the hexane solution of the equimolar amounts of Cu(hfac)2 and LMe/Et. The synthesis of [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et] is reproducible, and no impurities with another stoichiometry were recorded in the product. The structural study of [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et] showed that under the normal conditions, its solid phase is formed by [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et] n  polymer chains, in which the nitroxide molecules are orientated according to the head-to-head motif (). Each LMe/Et molecule performs the bridging function and is coordinated by the alternating Cu atoms or by the N atom of the pyrazole ring or the O atom of the nitronyl nitroxyl fragment.

elements.content: Cu–ONO and Cu–N distances (Å) in [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et] at different temperatures.
elements.clean_text: 1  Cu-ONO and Cu-N distances (Å) in [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et] at different temperatures.

elements.content: When the compound is cooled from 295 to 240 K, a structural phase transition takes place, as a result of which the volume of the unit cell and, accordingly, its crystallographically independent part double (Table 1S). As a result, instead of one {CuO6} centrosymmetric unit with Cu(1)–ONO distances of 2.353(2) Å (290 K) at 240 K, two centrosymmetric units of this type (Cu(1) and Cu(3)) appear, in which the Cu–ONO distances differ: 2.351(2) and 2.310(2) Å (). The {CuO4N2} coordination units, which are centrosymmetric at room temperature (Cu(2)–N 2.568(3) Å), become noncentrosymmetric at 240 K. One of the axial Cu(2)–N distances is shortened to 2.538(3) Å, and the other is lengthened by 0.176 and becomes 2.744(3) Å (d3 and d2 in , respectively). The polymer-chain structure is actually destroyed, and the compound transforms into a pair complex consisting of the mononuclear [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et 2] and trinuclear [[Cu­(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2] centrosymmetric fragments (, 240 K), in which the {CuO6} coordination units differ in the Cu–ONO distances.
elements.clean_text: When the compound is cooled from 295 to 240 K, a structural phase transition takes place, as a result of which the volume of the unit cell and, accordingly, its crystallographically independent part double (Table 1S). As a result, instead of one {CuO6} centrosymmetric unit with Cu(1)-ONO distances of 2.353(2) Å (290 K) at 240 K, two centrosymmetric units of this type (Cu(1) and Cu(3)) appear, in which the Cu-ONO distances differ: 2.351(2) and 2.310(2) Å (). The {CuO4N2} coordination units, which are centrosymmetric at room temperature (Cu(2)-N 2.568(3) Å), become noncentrosymmetric at 240 K. One of the axial Cu(2)-N distances is shortened to 2.538(3) Å, and the other is lengthened by 0.176 and becomes 2.744(3) Å (d3 and d2 in , respectively). The polymer-chain structure is actually destroyed, and the compound transforms into a pair complex consisting of the mononuclear [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et 2] and trinuclear [[Cu(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2] centrosymmetric fragments (, 240 K), in which the {CuO6} coordination units differ in the Cu-ONO distances.

elements.content: Dependence μeff(T) for [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et] (closed black circles connected by black lines). The lines (violet d1, green d2, blue d3, red d4, and orange d5) reflect the dynamics of variation of the Cu(1)–ONO, Cu(2)–N, Cu(2)–N, Cu(3)–ONO, and Cu(3)–Ohfac distances, respectively. The lines connect the experimental bond lengths (Figure , Table 1S) at different temperatures (closed circles of the corresponding color).
elements.clean_text: 2  Dependence μeff(T) for [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et] (closed black circles connected by black lines). The lines (violet d1, green d2, blue d3, red d4, and orange d5) reflect the dynamics of variation of the Cu(1)-ONO, Cu(2)-N, Cu(2)-N, Cu(3)-ONO, and Cu(3)-Ohfac distances, respectively. The lines connect the experimental bond lengths (Figure  , Table 1S) at different temperatures (closed circles of the corresponding color).

elements.content: The structural transformation is accompanied by effect on the curve of the μeff(T) dependence. When the sample is cooled from 290 to 240 K, a small jump in μeff not related to spin transitions is observed (). It is caused by a change in the Cu environment in the {CuO4N2} units during the phase transition, during depolymerization.

When the sample is cooled from 290 to 240 K, a small jump in μeff not related to spin transitions is observed (). It is caused by a change in the Cu environment in the {CuO4N2} units during the phase transition, during depolymerization.

elements.content: When the [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et 2]­[[Cu­(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2] pair complex is further cooled from 240 to 85 K, the Cu(1)–ONO distances in the [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et 2] mononuclear fragment change but slightly (the violet line d1 in ), but in the environment of the “central” Cu(3) atom in the [[Cu­(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2] trinuclear fragment they shorten from 2.310(2) to 1.990(2) Å at 85 K, that is, by 0.32 Å (the red line d4 in ). The shortening of the Cu(3)–ONO bonds is accompanied by a lengthening of two Cu(3)–Ohfac bonds (the yellow line d5 in ). As a result, the direction of the Jahn–Teller axis in the environment of the “central” Cu atom in the [[Cu­(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2] trinuclear fragment changes during the phase transition.
elements.clean_text: When the [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et 2][[Cu(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2] pair complex is further cooled from 240 to 85 K, the Cu(1)-ONO distances in the [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et 2] mononuclear fragment change but slightly (the violet line d1 in ), but in the environment of the "central" Cu(3) atom in the [[Cu(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2] trinuclear fragment they shorten from 2.310(2) to 1.990(2) Å at 85 K, that is, by 0.32 Å (the red line d4 in ). The shortening of the Cu(3)-ONO bonds is accompanied by a lengthening of two Cu(3)-Ohfac bonds (the yellow line d5 in ). As a result, the direction of the Jahn-Teller axis in the environment of the "central" Cu atom in the [[Cu(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2] trinuclear fragment changes during the phase transition.

elements.content: When the temperature is lowered, μeff remains constant from 240 to 150 K, after which it decreases drastically from 2.52 to 2.24 μB in the range 150–140 K. As mentioned above, in this range, the direction of the elongated ONO–Cu–ONO axis in the bipyramid of the “central” Cu atom of the trinuclear fragment changes, and the Cu–ONO distances are shortened by more than 0.3 Å. This brings about strong antiferromagnetic exchange interactions in the {>N–•O–Cu2+–O•–N<} exchange clusters, as confirmed by the data of quantum-chemical calculations given below ().

As mentioned above, in this range, the direction of the elongated ONO-Cu-ONO axis in the bipyramid of the "central" Cu atom of the trinuclear fragment changes, and the Cu-ONO distances are shortened by more than 0.3 Å. This brings about strong antiferromagnetic exchange interactions in the {>N-⋅O-Cu2+-O⋅-N<} exchange clusters, as confirmed by the data of quantum-chemical calculations given below ().

When the sample is heated, the rearrangement of the {CuO6} coordination units and the polymerization accompanied by an abrupt increase in μeff occur at higher temperatures, ∼155 and 275 K, respectively. This leads to two hysteresis loops with a width of 17 and 23 K on the μeff(T) curve.

This leads to two hysteresis loops with a width of 17 and 23 K on the μeff(T) curve.

elements.content: Thus, when the cooling–heating cycles are repeated, the solid multispin compound undergoes a thermally induced reversible coordination reaction of depolymerization–polymerization: n[Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et] ⇆ n/4­[Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et 2]­[[Cu­(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2]. This process leads to two phase transitions accompanied by hysteresis loops on the μeff(T) curve: high-temperature (T↑ = 283 K, T↓ = 260 K) and low-temperature (T↑ = 161 K, T↓ = 144 K) transitions. The high-temperature process is caused by the depolymerization and structural rearrangement accompanied by the doubling of the unit cell volume. In the course of the low-temperature transition, the Jahn–Teller axis of Cu­(II) is reorientated in half of all {CuO6} units, in which the Cu–ONO bond lengths drastically decrease, while the Cu–Ohfac bond lengths increase (red and yellow lines, ). The significant shortening of the Cu–ONO bonds leads to a change of the ferromagnetic exchange to the antiferromagnetic one in the {>N–•O–Cu2+–O•–N<} exchange clusters, which just causes the low-temperature jump of μeff.

This process leads to two phase transitions accompanied by hysteresis loops on the μeff(T) curve: high-temperature (T↑ = 283 K, T↓ = 260 K) and low-temperature (T↑ = 161 K, T↓ = 144 K) transitions. The high-temperature process is caused by the depolymerization and structural rearrangement accompanied by the doubling of the unit cell volume. In the course of the low-temperature transition, the Jahn-Teller axis of Cu(II) is reorientated in half of all {CuO6} units, in which the Cu-ONO bond lengths drastically decrease, while the Cu-Ohfac bond lengths increase (red and yellow lines, ). The significant shortening of the Cu-ONO bonds leads to a change of the ferromagnetic exchange to the antiferromagnetic one in the {>N-⋅O-Cu2+-O⋅-N<} exchange clusters, which just causes the low-temperature jump of μeff.

elements.content: The position of the thermal effects on the experimental temperature dependence of the molar heat capacity of the polycrystalline [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et] sample (Figures 2S and 3S) agrees well with the indicated temperature ranges of magnetic anomalies. Data processing for the C p(T) dependence for [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et] allowed us to obtain the thermodynamic characteristics ΔH 0 = 474.1 J/mol and ΔS 0 = 1.720 J/Kmol (T max ≈ 276.5 K) for the transition in the range 268–288 K and ΔH 0 = 329.1 J/mol and ΔS 0 = 1.991 J/Kmol (T max ≈ 164.5 K) for the transition in the range 156–176 K. The small values of thermal effects suggest that there is no pronounced overheating or overcooling even after a sudden crossing of the phase boundary in the crystals of the heterospin complex, which prevents their cracking and favors the SC–SC transition. Quantum-chemical calculations for the [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et 2] model complex containing the {CuO4N2} coordination unit (Figure 4S) suggest that the distortions that accompany the high-temperature structural phase transition are not energy-consuming (the structures with and without asymmetry in the Cu–N distances differ in energy by only ∼300 J/mol).
elements.clean_text: The position of the thermal effects on the experimental temperature dependence of the molar heat capacity of the polycrystalline [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et] sample (Figures 2S and 3S) agrees well with the indicated temperature ranges of magnetic anomalies. Data processing for the C p(T) dependence for [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et] allowed us to obtain the thermodynamic characteristics ΔH 0 = 474.1 J/mol and ΔS 0 = 1.720 J/Kmol (T max ~ 276.5 K) for the transition in the range 268-288 K and ΔH 0 = 329.1 J/mol and ΔS 0 = 1.991 J/Kmol (T max ~ 164.5 K) for the transition in the range 156-176 K. The small values of thermal effects suggest that there is no pronounced overheating or overcooling even after a sudden crossing of the phase boundary in the crystals of the heterospin complex, which prevents their cracking and favors the SC-SC transition. Quantum-chemical calculations for the [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et 2] model complex containing the {CuO4N2} coordination unit (Figure 4S) suggest that the distortions that accompany the high-temperature structural phase transition are not energy-consuming (the structures with and without asymmetry in the Cu-N distances differ in energy by only ~300 J/mol).

elements.content: The quantum-chemical calculations of exchange interactions were performed in the molecular (ORCA 3.0 and Gaussian 09 packages) and band structure (Quantum Espresso 5.0 package) variants. The results of calculations in both variants showed that at low temperatures (T < 150 K), the {>N–•O–Cu­(II)–O•–N<} three-spin exchange clusters containing Cu(1) atoms () have a relatively insignificant ferromagnetic exchange interaction, while the {>N–•O–Cu­(II)–O•–N<} three-spin exchange clusters containing the Cu(3) atoms () have a strong antiferromagnetic spin ordering. In the high-temperature phase, the exchange spin coupling is ferromagnetic in all the three-spin exchange clusters (). An important result of calculation is that it revealed a significant antiferromagnetic exchange between the nitroxyl groups of the radicals of the neighboring polymer chains over the whole temperature range (the distance between the {>N–•O} groups changes from 3.625 Å at 85 K to 4.232 Å at 290 K). At the same time, the calculations did not confirm any significant exchange (<0.1 cm–1) between the one-spin ({CuO4N2} coordination units) and three-spin ({CuO6} coordination units) clusters along the polymer chains. Thus, the [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et] crystal has a magnetic chain of alternating three-spin exchange clusters of both types, which differs from the structural chain, and a magnetically isolated “layer” of one-spin {CuO4N2} coordination units.

elements.content: Experimental (black circles) and theoretical effective magnetic moment μeff for [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et]. The theoretical points were obtained using the magnetic coupling constants calculated by the DFT methods (Table ): UB3LYP/def2-TZVP (red triangles and line); GGA+U (blue squares and line); and GGA+U with neglect of the interchain magnetic coupling J 0 (green dashed line). The g-factors of Cu­(II) and radicals were taken to be 2.15 and 2.05, respectively. The exchange parameters calculated for the crystal structure at 85 K were used for T < 150 K, at 240 K for 150 < T < 256 K, and at 290 K for T > 256 K.

elements.content: Below 140 K three-spin exchange clusters containing the Cu(3) atoms with strong internal antiferromagnetism are the paramagnetic centers with effective spin S = 1/2. On the basis of mathematical considerations, one can show that these centers are linked into a magnetic chain with neighboring three-spin exchange clusters containing Cu(1) atoms via the effective exchange parameter J 0(eff) = (2/3)J 0 < 0.

On the basis of mathematical considerations, one can show that these centers are linked into a magnetic chain with neighboring three-spin exchange clusters containing Cu(1) atoms via the effective exchange parameter J 0(eff) = (2/3)J 0 < 0.

elements.content: Thus, at T < 140 K the magnetic chain consists of alternating three-spin exchange clusters and one-spin fragments. At lowered temperatures, the effective spins 1/2 are aligned oppositely to the spins of the three-spin clusters. This is associated with the initial decrease in the total effective magnetic moment below 140 K. In the three-spin exchange clusters with the positive exchange integral, spin alignment into the state with the resulting spin S = 3/2 occurs concurrently. This leads to an increase in the effective magnetic moment of the compound at lowered temperatures after reaching a certain minimum at 20 K ( and ).

elements.content: The mutually complementary data of and for the range 150–160 K show that in complexes with spin-labeled pyrazoles, a spin transition can occur in molecular solid phases. Can we regard the {[Cu­(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2} fragments responsible for the spin transition as individual trinuclear molecules, for which the shortest distance to the adjacent {Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et 2} mononuclear fragments is ∼2.7 Å ()? The Cu–N distance, which is 2.568(3) Å at 290 K, can be regarded (based on XRD data and structural criteria developed for Jahn–Teller ions) as a quite admissible axial distance. It follows from the CCDC statistical database (November 2014; version 5.36; updates May 2015) that in the compound containing a Cu···O–N fragment, two types of Cu–O distances are most characteristic: 1.9–2.0 and 2.3–2.6 Å, which correspond to the position of the O atoms in the equatorial plane of the Cu bipyramid and in the axial positions, respectively. For the Cu–N bond, the most characteristic distances are 1.9–2.3 Å. Fewer distances lie in the range 2.3–2.6 Å (Figure 1S). For [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et] at 240 K (i.e., after the phase transformation), however, the Cu–N distance (2.744(3) Å) is certainly too long, and we can suppose that the Cu–N chemical bond is absent in the fragments in question. Consequently, for solids with a molecular structure, spin transitions are possible in Cu­(II) complexes with spin-labeled pyrazoles; previously, the transitions were recorded only for polymer chain compounds or cyclic dimers. This is an important result, which affects further development of the theoretical description of spin transitions in heterospin systems. Note that previous attempts to synthesize these compounds failed.

This is an important result, which affects further development of the theoretical description of spin transitions in heterospin systems. Note that previous attempts to synthesize these compounds failed.

elements.content: Selective synthesis of heterospin molecular compounds capable of exhibiting a spin transition is problematic because it is very difficult to predict the required modification of the paramagnetic organic molecule. The situation is further complicated by the fact that temperature variation initiates many coherent intra- and intermolecular motions of atoms, which provide the mechanical stability of the single crystal as an entity, especially during the phase transformation. In addition, copper heterospin complexes with nitroxides are stereochemically nonrigid compounds, and hence one can isolate many heterospin complexes using the same paramagnetic ligand depending on the synthesis conditions and reagent ratio. Therefore, we had to perform a few hundred experiments before we managed to isolate molecular Cu­(hfac)2 complexes with pyrazolyl-substituted nitronyl nitroxides that exhibit spin crossover by varying the set of R and R′ substituents in the pyrazole ring, the reagent ratio, solvent, and synthesis conditions.

elements.content: The experimental μeff(T) dependence for [[Cu­(hfac)2]3LBu/Et 2] is shown in . At room temperature μeff is 4.14 μB, which corresponds to five noninteracting paramagnetic centers with spin S = 1/2, two of which have g = 2.0, and the other three have g = 2.22. When the complex is cooled from 170 to 150 K, μeff decreases to 3.97 μB. When the complex is cooled from 140 to 105 K, μeff smoothly decreases to ∼3.60 μB, and then further to 3.13 μB with a plateau at 60 K. This value corresponds to three noninteracting paramagnetic centers with spin S = 1/2, two of which have g ≈ 2.15, and the third one has g = 2.0. The form of the μeff(T) dependence for [[Cu­(hfac)2]3LBu/Et 2], which is very similar to the dependence described previously for the [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/H] polymer chain complex, points to a spin transition in the heterospin complex. Regretfully, the single crystals of the compound decomposed during the X-ray diffraction experiment, which precluded the obtaining of data on the temperature dynamics of the structure of [[Cu­(hfac)2]3LBu/Et 2] below 170 K.

elements.content: When the products of the reaction of Cu­(hfac)2 and LBu/Et were studied, one more molecular complex was isolated with an unusual Cu­(hfac)2/paramagnetic ligand ratio (5/4). [[Cu­(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] is a kinetic product that can be obtained as described in the . The crystal structure of the compound is formed by the centrosymmetric [[Cu­(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] molecules (). The vertices of the square bipyramid of the central Cu1 atom are occupied by the O atoms of NO groups (Cu(1)–ONO = 2.303(3) Å, ). The donor N atoms of the ligand occupy one of the vertices of the square bipyramids at the Cu(2) atom of the {Cu(2)­O5N} coordination units at a distance of 2.388(3) Å. The environment is completed by the O atom of the NO group of the neighboring LBu/Et molecule with a distance of 2.683(3) Å. The terminal Cu(3) atoms have a square pyramidal environment and coordinate one ONO atom of the paramagnetic ligand. The Cu(3)–ONO distance is short, 1.960(2) Å. Note that two of the four LBu/Et molecules are coordinated by the copper ions via the N atoms of the pyrazole ring and one of the O atoms of the NO groups, while the other two LBu/Et molecules perform the bridging function only via the O atoms of the paramagnetic fragment of the ligand.

elements.content: Further cooling of the compound leads to a structural transition and the ensuing spin transition (). Despite the considerable rearrangements of coordination units, the phase transition occurs without crystal decay during the repeated cooling–heating cycles, which allowed us to trace the structural dynamics of the complex.

elements.content: The μeff value at 300 K tends to 4.01 μB corresponding to a system of five weakly interacting centers with spin 1/2 and g = 2.07. The contribution of two terminal copper ions and two LBu/Et coordinated by these ions is absent because of the dominance of strong antiferromagnetic interactions (), which lead to compensation of spins already at room temperature.

elements.content: In the temperature range 80–5 K, μeff corresponds to three independent spins with S = 1/2 and an average g-factor of ∼2.13, which agrees with the data on the structural rearrangement of solid [[Cu­(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] and the appearance of strong antiferromagnetic exchange interactions in the {>N–•O–Cu2+–•O–N<} clusters that lead to spin compensation ().

elements.content: According to the exchange parameters for the available temperature points given in , the theoretical calculation of μeff () does not reproduce the experimental curve of the effective magnetic moment quite accurately. The agreement with experiment can be improved if the [[Cu­(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] system is considered to be in one of two geometrical configurations corresponding to the low-temperature (LT) or high-temperature (HT) phases. In this case, the magnetostructural transition is a smooth change in the ratio between two phases with temperature. This assumption was confirmed by the broadening of the diffraction peaks in the transition region and was earlier used in communications. The corresponding fractions of the LT phase were calculated based on the assumption that d T ( Cu − O ) = w d LT ( Cu − O ) + ( 1 − w ) d HT ( Cu − O ) where d T(Cu–O) is the Cu–O bond length in the three-spin {>N–•O–Cu2+–•O–N<} cluster in the available temperature points according to XRD data. The calculated w values are given in . It was assumed that the LT phase corresponds to the structural solution at 110 K, while the HT phase, to the structural solution at 295 K. When constructing the theoretical curve μeff(T), we assumed that the fraction of the LT phase changed linearly between the available temperature points. The resulting “weighted” curve is above the experimental curve at high temperatures and below it at low temperatures. This may be due to both the overestimated exchange parameters and the inaccurate g-factors of the paramagnetic centers (for theoretical evaluation, the values characteristic for “breathing” crystals were used, g R = 2.05 and g Cu = 2.15). Another important factor that influences the agreement between theory and experiment is the extended phase transition for the given system, so that even at T = 295 K the LT phase is still present in a substantial amount (∼15%).

elements.content: Thus, the results of our studies of [[Cu­(hfac)2]3LBu/Et 2] and [[Cu­(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] confirmed the possibility of thermally induced spin transitions in molecular heterospin complexes. Each of these compounds contains {>N–•O–Cu­(II)–O•–N<} three-center exchange clusters similar to those in [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et 2]­[[Cu­(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2]. The possibility of SC–SC phase transformations in crystals allowed us to show directly that the recorded spin transitions are the consequence of significant structural changes in heterospin exchange clusters, which provoke spin transitions.
elements.clean_text: Thus, the results of our studies of [[Cu(hfac)2]3LBu/Et 2] and [[Cu(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] confirmed the possibility of thermally induced spin transitions in molecular heterospin complexes. Each of these compounds contains {>N-⋅O-Cu(II)-O⋅-N<} three-center exchange clusters similar to those in [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et 2][[Cu(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2]. The possibility of SC-SC phase transformations in crystals allowed us to show directly that the recorded spin transitions are the consequence of significant structural changes in heterospin exchange clusters, which provoke spin transitions.

elements.content: As a result of this study, heterospin complexes [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et], [[Cu­(hfac)2]3LBu/Et 2], and [[Cu­(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] were synthesized. The single crystals of the compounds possess high mechanical plasticity, which allowed us to study their SC–SC phase transformations. For [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et] crystals, a cascade of reversible transformations was found during repeated cooling–heating cycles in the range 5–325 K including coordination depolymerization–polymerization: n[Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et] ⇆ n/4­[Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et 2]­[[Cu­(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2] and spin transition. It is important to note that depolymerization of the compound is caused by a decrease in temperature, which is a very rare occurrence. The cooling of the compounds generally decreases the thermal vibrations of atoms; this leads to a decrease in the interatomic distances and crystal compression. When the [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et] polymer was cooled and transformed into the [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et 2]­[[Cu­(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2] pair complex, the crystals were also compressed, and their density increased (Table 1S). However, this does not hinder the breaking of the polymer chains and further significant shortening of Cu–O bonds in the {>N–•O–Cu­(II)–O•–N<} exchange clusters of the {[Cu­(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2} trinuclear fragments. We can assume that the motive force of this process is the appearance of strong antiferromagnetic exchange between the paramagnetic centers inside the {>N–•O–Cu­(II)–O•–N<} exchange clusters at short Cu–ONO distances, which was confirmed by quantum-chemical calculations. The antiferromagnetic exchange is, in a sense, an analog of the chemical bond, and its appearance is some kind of additional contribution to the bond system in crystal. This is also indicated by our studies of the [Cu­(hfac)2] complexes with the diamagnetic structural analogs of nitroxides, which showed that a paramagnetic organic ligand should be present for the spin crossover to appear.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

As a result of this study, heterospin complexes [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et], [[Cu(hfac)2]3LBu/Et 2], and [[Cu(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4] were synthesized. The single crystals of the compounds possess high mechanical plasticity, which allowed us to study their SC-SC phase transformations. For [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et] crystals, a cascade of reversible transformations was found during repeated cooling-heating cycles in the range 5-325 K including coordination depolymerization-polymerization: n[Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et] ⇆ n/4[Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et 2][[Cu(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2] and spin transition. It is important to note that depolymerization of the compound is caused by a decrease in temperature, which is a very rare occurrence. The cooling of the compounds generally decreases the thermal vibrations of atoms; this leads to a decrease in the interatomic distances and crystal compression. When the [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et] polymer was cooled and transformed into the [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et 2][[Cu(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2] pair complex, the crystals were also compressed, and their density increased (Table 1S). However, this does not hinder the breaking of the polymer chains and further significant shortening of Cu-O bonds in the {>N-⋅O-Cu(II)-O⋅-N<} exchange clusters of the {[Cu(hfac)2]3LMe/Et 2} trinuclear fragments. We can assume that the motive force of this process is the appearance of strong antiferromagnetic exchange between the paramagnetic centers inside the {>N-⋅O-Cu(II)-O⋅-N<} exchange clusters at short Cu-ONO distances, which was confirmed by quantum-chemical calculations. The antiferromagnetic exchange is, in a sense, an analog of the chemical bond, and its appearance is some kind of additional contribution to the bond system in crystal. This is also indicated by our studies of the [Cu(hfac)2] complexes with the diamagnetic structural analogs of nitroxides, which showed that a paramagnetic organic ligand should be present for the spin crossover to appear.

1-Methyl-3-ethylpyrazole (11.02 g, 0.1 mol) was dissolved in DMF (36 g, 0.5 mol), and POCl3 was added dropwise (30.66 g, 0.2 mol). The reaction mixture was stirred for 5 h at 70–75 °C and then poured in cold water (200 mL); pH of the solution was brought to 7 or 8 with a saturated NaHCO3 solution. The precipitate was filtered off and dried in air. Yield: 8.28 g (60%). T b = 132–134 °C/15 Torr. 1H NMR spectrum (δ, ppm, J H,H, Hz) (400.13 MHz), CDCl3: 1.26 t (3H, CH3, J = 7.6), 2.86 qu (2H CH2, J = 7.6), 3.88 s (3H, NCH3), 7.82 s (1H, C5H), 9.86 s (1H, HCO). Found (%): C 60.9; H 7.3; N 20.3. Calculated for C7H10N2O (%): C 60.8; H 7.4; N 20.1. A mixture of 1-butyl-3(5)-ethyl-1H-pyrazole-4-carboxaldehydes was prepared from 1-butyl-3(5)-ethylpyrazoles (15.24 g, 0.1 mol), DMF (36 g, 0.5 mol), and POCl3 (30.66 g, 0.2 mol) by the same procedure. Yield: 12.24 g (68%); isomer ratio ≈ 1:1. T b = 150–154 °C/15 Torr). Found (%): C 66.6; H 9.0; N 15.5. Calculated for C10H16N2O (%): C 66.8; H 8.9; N 15.6.

A solution of 2,3-bis­(hydroxyamino)-2,3-dimethylbutane sulfate hydrate (3.15 g, 11.8 mmol) in water (50 mL) and a mixture of 1-butyl-3(5)-ethyl-1H-pyrazole-4-carboxaldehyde (1.8 g, 10.0 mmol) with Et2O (15 mL) was stirred for 4 h at room temperature and treated with NaHCO3 until CO2 ceased to evolve. The resulting precipitate was filtered off, washed with water and acetone, and dried in a vacuum desiccator. The resulting adduct (1.35 g, 4.4 mmol) was stirred in CH3OH (7 mL) with MnO2 (6.75 g, 77.5 mmol) for 1.5 h. The reaction mixture was filtered, and the precipitate washed with CH3OH. The filtrate was evaporated, and the residue dissolved in a minimum amount of ethyl acetate. The resulting solution was filtered through a silica gel layer (1.5 × 15 cm) and evaporated. The nitroxides containing a butyl and ethyl substituent in the first and third positions of the pyrazole ring (LBu/Et) or in the first and fifth positions of the pyrazole ring (LBu/Et*), respectively, were prepared as a mixture of blue oily products. Yield: 1.1 g (82%). IR (KBr, cm–1): ν = 3415 (m), 3124 (w), 2961 (s), 2873 (s), 1678 (s), 1585 (s), 1541 (m), 1508 (m), 1456 (s), 1395 (s), 1358 (s), 1320 (m), 1221 (m), 1173 (s), 1141 (s), 1114 (w), 1058 (w), 1012 (w), 962 (w), 871 (m), 830 (m), 791 (w), 761 (w), 655 (w), 614 (w), 541 (m), 463 (w). The high-resolution mass spectrum was recorded on Thermo Electron DFS (EI 70 eV, 10–7 mTorr, direct insertion probe on a heated stock). Found: m/z 307.2130 [M+]. C16H27N4O2. Calculated: M = 307.2129. Mass spectrum, m/z (I rel(%)): 41.0 (14.2), 69.1 (35.9), 84.1 (100), 98.1 (19.8), 178.1 (12.1), 275.2 (12.7), 307.2 (42.2).

2-(1-Methyl-3-ethyl-1<italic>H</italic>-pyrazol-4-yl)-4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-4,5-dihydro-1<italic>H</italic>-imidazole-3-oxide-1-oxyl (L<sup>Me/Et</sup>)

A solution of 2,3-bis­(hydroxyamino)-2,3-dimethylbutane (0.7 g, 4.7 mmol) and 3-ethyl-1-methyl-1H-pyrazole-4-carboxaldehyde (0.53 g, 3.8 mmol) in CH3OH (5 mL) was stirred for 6 h at room temperature in an Ar atmosphere. The resulting precipitate was filtered off, dried, and stirred in CH3OH (7 mL) with MnO2 (4.8 g, 55 mmol) for 4 h. The reaction mixture was filtered, and the precipitate washed with CH3OH. The filtrate was evaporated, and the residue dissolved in a minimum amount of ethyl acetate. The solution was filtered through a silica gel layer (1.5 × 15 cm) and evaporated. The product was recrystallized from hexane. The dark blue crystals of the radical were filtered off and washed with cold hexane. Yield: 0.81 g (84%). mp: 79–80 °C. Found (%): C, 59.0; H, 7.9; N, 21.3. C13H21N4O2. Calculated (%): C, 58.8; H, 8.0; N, 21.1. Synthesis of [Cu­(hfac)<sub>2</sub>L<sup>Me/Et</sup>]

A mixture of Cu­(hfac)2 (0.0477 g, 0.1 mmol) and LMe/Et (0.0266 g, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved, while slightly heating (55 °C), in hexane (4 mL). The reaction mixture was kept at room temperature for 30 min. The resulting dark brown crystals were filtered off and dried in air. Yield: 0.065 g (88%). Found (%): C, 37.0; H, 3.2; F, 30.4; N, 7.3. C23H23CuF12N4O6. Calculated (%): C, 37.2; H, 3.1; F, 30.7; N, 7.5. IR (KBr, cm–1): ν = 2978 (m), 1644 (s), 1584 (m), 1557 (m), 1528 (m), 1489 (m), 1393 (w), 1374 (w), 1346 (m), 1258 (s), 1207 (s), 1148 (s), 1105 (m), 1051 (w), 871 (w), 848 (w), 815 (w), 799 (s), 765 (w), 745 (w), 680 (s), 595 (m), 540 (m).

Synthesis of [[Cu­(hfac)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>3</sub>L<sup>Bu/Et</sup> <sub>2</sub>]

A mixture of Cu­(hfac)2 (0.0477 g, 0.1 mmol) and oily LBu/Et and LBu/Et* (0.0400 g, 0.13 mmol) was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (2 mL). The solution was evaporated, and the residue dissolved, while treating it ultrasonically, in hexane (2 mL). The resulting solution was cooled and stored at −30 °C for 6–8 h. The resulting dark red needle crystals of the poorly soluble [Cu­(hfac)2LBu/Et*]2 were filtered off and washed with cold hexane. The mother solution was heated to room temperature, and its volume was decreased to a few milliters, while blowing it with an air current, and then stored at −18 °C for another 30 h. The resulting brown crystals were separated by filtration. Yield: 0.0246 g (25%). Found (%): C, 36.6; H, 2.9; F, 32.9; N, 5.7. C62H60Cu3F36N8O16. Calculated (%): C, 36.4; H, 3.0; F, 33.4; N, 5.5. IR (KBr, cm–1): ν = 2969 (m), 1643 (s), 1595 (m), 1559 (m), 1529 (m), 1481 (s), 1396 (w), 1359 (m), 1263 (s), 1209 (s), 1147 (s), 872 (w), 850 (w), 800 (s), 769 (w), 746 (w), 679 (s), 595 (m), 530 (m).

Synthesis of [[Cu­(hfac)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>5</sub>L<sup>Bu/Et</sup> <sub>4</sub>]

A mixture of Cu­(hfac)2 (0.0477 g, 0.1 mmol) and oily LBu/Et and LBu/Et* (0.0307 g, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in Et2O (3 mL). Then hexane (3 mL) was added. The reaction mixture was cooled to −18 °C. After 3 days, the precipitated [Cu­(hfac)2LBu/Et*]2 crystals were separated by filtration. 1-Methyl-3-ethylpyrazole (11.02 g, 0.1 mol) was dissolved in DMF (36 g, 0.5 mol), and POCl3 was added dropwise (30.66 g, 0.2 mol). The reaction mixture was stirred for 5 h at 70-75 °C and then poured in cold water (200 mL); pH of the solution was brought to 7 or 8 with a saturated NaHCO3 solution. The precipitate was filtered off and dried in air. Yield: 8.28 g (60%). Found (%): C 60.9; H 7.3; N 20.3. Calculated for C7H10N2O (%): C 60.8; H 7.4; N 20.1. A mixture of 1-butyl-3(5)-ethyl-1H-pyrazole-4-carboxaldehydes was prepared from 1-butyl-3(5)-ethylpyrazoles (15.24 g, 0.1 mol), DMF (36 g, 0.5 mol), and POCl3 (30.66 g, 0.2 mol) by the same procedure. Yield: 12.24 g (68%); isomer ratio ~ 1:1. T b = 150-154 °C/15 Torr). Found (%): C 66.6; H 9.0; N 15.5. Calculated for C10H16N2O (%): C 66.8; H 8.9; N 15.6.

The resulting precipitate was filtered off, washed with water and acetone, and dried in a vacuum desiccator. The resulting adduct (1.35 g, 4.4 mmol) was stirred in CH3OH (7 mL) with MnO2 (6.75 g, 77.5 mmol) for 1.5 h. The reaction mixture was filtered, and the precipitate washed with CH3OH. The filtrate was evaporated, and the residue dissolved in a minimum amount of ethyl acetate. The resulting solution was filtered through a silica gel layer (1.5 × 15 cm) and evaporated. The nitroxides containing a butyl and ethyl substituent in the first and third positions of the pyrazole ring (LBu/Et) or in the first and fifth positions of the pyrazole ring (LBu/Et*), respectively, were prepared as a mixture of blue oily products. cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Cu-ONO and Cu-N distances (Å) in [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et] at different temperatures.

cln_elements.content: Dependence μeff(T) for [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et] (closed black circles connected by black lines). The lines (violet d1, green d2, blue d3, red d4, and orange d5) reflect the dynamics of variation of the Cu(1)–ONO, Cu(2)–N, Cu(2)–N, Cu(3)–ONO, and Cu(3)–Ohfac distances, respectively. The lines connect the experimental bond lengths (Figure , Table 1S) at different temperatures (closed circles of the corresponding color).
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Dependence μeff(T) for [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et] (closed black circles connected by black lines). The lines (violet d1, green d2, blue d3, red d4, and orange d5) reflect the dynamics of variation of the Cu(1)-ONO, Cu(2)-N, Cu(2)-N, Cu(3)-ONO, and Cu(3)-Ohfac distances, respectively. The lines connect the experimental bond lengths (Figure  , Table 1S) at different temperatures (closed circles of the corresponding color).

cln_elements.content: Experimental (black circles) and theoretical effective magnetic moment μeff for [Cu­(hfac)2LMe/Et]. The theoretical points were obtained using the magnetic coupling constants calculated by the DFT methods (Table ): UB3LYP/def2-TZVP (red triangles and line); GGA+U (blue squares and line); and GGA+U with neglect of the interchain magnetic coupling J 0 (green dashed line). The g-factors of Cu­(II) and radicals were taken to be 2.15 and 2.05, respectively. The exchange parameters calculated for the crystal structure at 85 K were used for T < 150 K, at 240 K for 150 < T < 256 K, and at 290 K for T > 256 K.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Experimental (black circles) and theoretical effective magnetic moment μeff for [Cu(hfac)2LMe/Et]. The theoretical points were obtained using the magnetic coupling constants calculated by the DFT methods (Table  ): UB3LYP/def2-TZVP (red triangles and line); GGA+U (blue squares and line); and GGA+U with neglect of the interchain magnetic coupling J 0 (green dashed line). The g-factors of Cu(II) and radicals were taken to be 2.15 and 2.05, respectively. The exchange parameters calculated for the crystal structure at 85 K were used for T < 150 K, at 240 K for 150 < T < 256 K, and at 290 K for T > 256 K.

Experimental (black circles) and theoretical effective magnetic moment μeff for [[Cu­(hfac)2]5LBu/Et 4]. The theoretical points were obtained using the magnetic coupling constants calculated by the DFT methods (Table ): UB3LYP/TZVP (blue), UB3LYP/def2-TZVP (red), and GGA+U (green). The symbols (blue triangles, red squares, and green stars) correspond to calculations using the magnetic coupling parameters of Table . The solid lines correspond to the weighting of the LT and HT phases at each temperature with fractions w (Table ). The g-factors of Cu­(II) and radicals were taken to be 2.15 and 2.05, respectively.

The symbols (blue triangles, red squares, and green stars) correspond to calculations using the magnetic coupling parameters of Table  .
